resources.string: Welcome to the T2 Mood Tracker

With this app you can rate your moods, keep track of how you’re feeling over time, figure out how life events, therapies and medications are affecting your well-being, and accurately communicate all of this to your health care provider or therapist should you choose to do so.
Choose a category by moving the slider below.
Rate yourself by sliding the pointers to a place that represents how you are feeling.

Rating your mood is quick and easy. Simply select a category you’d like to track. If you select “Depression” you will see a screen that has ten pairs of feelings, for example, “Happy”—“Sad”. Use your finger to move the pointer to a place on each of the ten lines that best represents how you are feeling. When you click submit, you will see a graph of all of your ratings with your most recent rating to the right.
View graphs of your previous ratings

Results of your ratings are always displayed by graphed lines. The RED line is made up of points representing the average of the ten ratings you made for each tracking category. The individual ratings you made for each separate mood are displayed on top of the average line in different colors so you can compare your average rating with each individual rating. For example, you can view the average of all ten ratings you made as you tracked “Depression” and you can view each of your ten individual ratings like “Happy-Sad”. The lower your line on the X axis, the more “negative” your rating. By moving the VERTICLE line on each graph with your finger you can see the dates of each recorded rating. The small black squares at the top of the graph are Note Indicators and indicate the dates you made notes. You can read your past notes by moving the vertical line to each Note Indicator and click the notes check in the upper right hand corner.
Use the slider above to view a different chart.
Add a note for today by clicking the + button.
Create a custom category to fit your needs. This new category will be available in the slider below.
Get additional information on how to use this app.
Allow developers to determine how this App is being used.
Review/Edit/Delete notes associated with days of the month.

Making notes of events that might be related to your moods is important. By touching the “Note” icon you can enter notes for the day of your rating. You can also go back to earlier ratings and make a note for that day. Make notes when you start, change or discontinue a medication or therapy, or note important events that occur each day. As you review your ratings over time you may be able to find important patterns in how you are feeling and why.
You do not have any notes yet.
Are you sure you would like to delete this note?
Require a password to view notes.
Notes have been unlocked for 1 hour.
Force the notes screen require a password next time it is visited.
Notes will require a password next time it is accessed.
This will clear all the ratings you have provided for this category. Are you sure you would like to do this?
Ratings data has been clear for this category.
Set a reminder to track your mood.
The time at which you will be reminded to rate your mood.
Adjust how the app should operate.
Notes will require a password next time it is accessed.

Mood Tracker was developed by the National Center for Telehealth and Technology (T2) to provide a quick and easy way of tracking your moods and behavior on a regular basis. You can view your ratings on easy to read graphs. You can also make notes describing things that happened during the day that might have affected your moods. This gives you a complete tool to look for patterns in how you are feeling over time. You may share your ratings or keep them for your own use.
Remove this category, associated scales and ratings.
Change the name of this Category.
List and modify this category\'s scales.
Remove all the rating associated with this category.
How often would you like to be reminded to rate your mood?
The password entered is not correct. Enter the current password.
The passwords did not match. Enter the new password.
Are you sure you would like to delete this category and all of its rating scales?
Add a category or delete all data from any category.
This category and its rating scales cannot be modified.
The rating scale has been saved.
Are you sure you would like to delete this rating scale and all of the values you\'ve provided?
Copy a Scale from an existing Category.
Set a reminder to track your mood.
Choose how long since your last entry you should be reminded to take this activity.
A category of rating scales needs to be taken.
A category of rating scales needs to be taken.
You will be returned to your current activity when finished.

string-array.name: startup_tips
string-array.item: The body is vulnerable to problems when it is not “maintained” properly. Take timeout to relax or do enjoyable activities.
Put effort into maintaining positive relationships at work. After deployment you still need someone to watch your back.
Blowing off steam is a bad idea: anger creates more anger, and stress creates more stress. Solve the problem.
Problems with drinking and drugs can be tough to work through on your own. Talk to a chaplain or health care professional.
Getting involved in your community and spending time with others can help you feel less alone and allows you to give back to your community.
Talking about feelings, although uncomfortable, is an important step to getting past grief.
It’s common for depressed people to believe that nothing will help. Today\'s treatments for depression are very effective.
If you\'re depressed avoid the urge to be alone. Be with other people. Confide in someone – it’s healthier than self-isolating.
Balance your life--don\'t let your day define your priorities, let your priorities define your day.
If you\'re feeling guilty about something remember that self-forgiveness means recognizing mistakes and accepting shortcomings.
Don\'t believe everything you think: Challenge your negative thoughts. Is there evidence to support the way you are perceiving the situation?
It\'s not the event that causes stress, it\'s how you interpret the event. Changing your "all or nothing thinking" will allow you to reduce stress.
If staying focused at work is a problem, jotting in a notebook or using a journal can be helpful
One source of anger is fear. The next time you get angry, ask yourself what made you afraid. If you work on the fear, the anger will get better.
To break the habit of aggressive behavior, it is necessary to become aware of what triggers or sets off the anger.
There is a difference between feelings and behavior – an individual may feel angry but the anger does not have to be acted on in an aggressive way.
There are often feelings behind anger that make the anger stronger like fear which can be based on embarrassment, powerlessness, frustration and hurt.
Try to avoid words like “should,” “shouldn’t,” “must,” “ought,” “always,” “have to,” or “need to”. Statements including these words tend to increase anger.
If you are struggling with spiritual question, take the time to talk to someone you trust.
Participating in activities with family, friends, or a larger community adds to your spiritual fitness by increasing your connection to other people.
The ability to make sense of a traumatic event in a way that ‘fits’ with one\'s previous beliefs may lead to psychological or spiritual growth
Research shows that when people forgive others, they become less vengeful, and more generous and kind toward others.
If you are coping with an injury, remember to set some goals. Goal-setting is important for both your physical recovery and for positive mental health.
If you are struggling with chronic pain, don\'t give up. Be open to trying different treatments or combinations of treatments until you find something that works for you.
